Keep in mind that this is only the first version of this endpoint and moving forward we can do much more with it, if we think it'll be useful for us and our users."}, {'account_id': 29124, 'date': '2019-02-05 09:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)

IMO, it could be useful to get some info about retries (which tasks retries a lot or something like this), so it could be signal that something could be wrong in external services and we could do some actions to prevent this unstable situation in future tasks.'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2019-02-05 12:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2019-02-05 12:04:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I agree with log comment from Oleg but that's a minor nitpicking"}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-02-06 06:43:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)

Addressed Oleg's comments. The new patch is on its way."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-02-06 06:44:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-02-06 06:52:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Oleg, as for your comment about retries, this info is actually available now because if there were many retries of a task it will have more than one action/workflow execution associated with it. Those iterations that were not accepted will have a value of the flag 'accepted' set to False. I realise that it might not be the most convenient form though. But yes, we can add more info to make it more clear, say a task execution can have an explicit field "number_of_retries".

Good stuff, thanks. Like I said, we can add much more things into this report that would be useful for debugging. Keep suggesting. For that one, I'll create a ticket.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-02-06 06:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

'}, {'created': '2019-02-04 07:32:54.000000000', 'message': 'Add a workflow execution report endpoint

* This patch adds the first version of the REST endpoint that
  can generate a report for a workflow execution. Without any
  query parameters, GET method of the endpoint returns a tree-like
  structure that includes information about all execution objects
  associate with the specified workflow execution. The root object
  is the workflow execution itself, its children are task executions,
  each task execution has either action executions or workflow
  executions and so on. So the structure describes the entire set
  of all execution objects regardless of how deep there are from the
  root object. This kind of data itself can be used to better
  understand and visualise the process related with a parent workflow,
  see what paths were taken while the workflow was running.
  If additional parameters are provided in a query string, the
  endpoint can give only a subset of the entire tree. Currently,
  the filters are:
    1. "errors_only" (boolean) to retain only all execution objects
        with the error state, meaning that only all error paths are
        present in the report. It is useful when we need to do a root
        cause analysis of the workflow failure. False by default.
    2. "max_depth" (integer) to limit how deep the algorithm can go
        into nested workflows. If set to 0 the only the root workflow
        execution will be in the report. If set to 1, then the report
        will have only the root workflow execution and its direct
	children. And so on. If negative (which is by default) then
        no limit is set.
  Additionally, the report contains statistics about task executions
  examined while the report was being generated, like the number of
  tasks in the error state, number of tasks that successfully
  finished and so on.
* Added all main tests for the endpoint. Note that despite the fact
  that this test verifies a REST API endpoint, unlike the other API
  tests it runs a Mistral engine to run workflows. This is done to
  simplify the test implementation so that we don't have to mock
  everything with huge data structures like we do in other API tests.

Possible changes that may be made based on the feedback:
* Statistics can contain not only number of tasks in certain states.
  We can also add things like number of actions, depth of the tree,
  number of nested workflows, average task/action/workflow execution
  time etc.
* Additional query parameters to configure a generated report. For
  example, "statistics_only" just to get a general information about
  the workflow execution tree, not the tree itself. Another example
  is "running_only" to retain only not finished workflow paths.

Implements blueprint: mistral-error-analysis

Change-Id: Id3e17821e04b7a1b84dfea5126d223d90ad8e3c2

    2. "max_depth" (integer) to limit how deep the algorithm can go
        into nested workflows. If set to 0, only the root workflow
        execution will be in the report. If set to 1, then the report
        will have only the root workflow execution and its direct
	children. And so on. If negative (by default) then no limit
        is set.
  Additionally, the report contains statistics about task executions
  examined while the report was being generated, like the number of
  tasks in the error state, number of tasks that successfully
  finished and so on.
* Added all main tests for the endpoint. Note that despite the fact
  that this test verifies a REST API endpoint, unlike the other API
  tests it runs a Mistral engine to run workflows. This is done to
  simplify the test implementation so that we don't have to mock
  everything with huge data structures like we do in other API tests.

Possible changes that may be made based on the feedback:
* Statistics can contain not only number of tasks in certain states.
  We can also add things like number of actions, depth of the tree,
  number of nested workflows, average task/action/workflow execution
  time etc.
* Additional query parameters to configure a generated report. For
  example, "statistics_only" just to get a general information about
  the workflow execution tree, not the tree itself. Another example
  is "running_only" to retain only not finished workflow paths.

Implements blueprint: mistral-error-analysis

Change-Id: Id3e17821e04b7a1b84dfea5126d223d90ad8e3c2

commit_message:
Add a workflow execution report endpoint

* This patch adds the first version of the REST endpoint that
  can generate a report for a workflow execution. Without any
  query parameters, GET method of the endpoint returns a tree-like
  structure that includes information about all execution objects
  associated with the specified workflow execution. The root object
  is the workflow execution itself, its children are task executions,
  each task execution has either action executions or workflow
  executions and so on. So the structure describes the entire set
  of execution objects regardless of how deep there are from the
  root object. This kind of data itself can be used to better
  understand and visualise the process related with a parent workflow,
  see what paths were taken while the workflow was running.
  If additional parameters are provided in a query string, the
  endpoint can give only a subset of the entire tree. Currently,
  the filters are:
    1. "errors_only" (boolean) to retain only all execution objects
        with the error state, meaning that only all error paths are
        present in the report. It is useful when we need to do a root
        cause analysis of the workflow failure. False by default.
    2. "max_depth" (integer) to limit how deep the algorithm can go
        into nested workflows. If set to 0, only the root workflow
        execution will be in the report. If set to 1, then the report
        will have only the root workflow execution and its direct
	children. And so on. If negative (by default) then no limit
        is set.
  Additionally, the report contains statistics about task executions
  examined while the report was being generated, like the number of
  tasks in the error state, number of tasks that successfully
  finished and so on.
* Added all main tests for the endpoint. Note that despite the fact
  that this test verifies a REST API endpoint, unlike the other API
  tests it runs a Mistral engine to run workflows. This is done to
  simplify the test implementation so that we don't have to mock
  everything with huge data structures like we do in other API tests.

Possible changes that may be made based on the feedback:
* Statistics can contain not only number of tasks in certain states.
  We can also add things like number of actions, depth of the tree,
  number of nested workflows, average task/action/workflow execution
  time etc.
* Additional query parameters to configure a generated report. For
  example, "statistics_only" just to get a general information about
  the workflow execution tree, not the tree itself. Another example
  is "running_only" to retain only not finished workflow paths.

Implements blueprint: mistral-error-analysis

Change-Id: Id3e17821e04b7a1b84dfea5126d223d90ad8e3c2

commit_message:
Retry adding custom repos until success

Previously we checked for false in the result. The behavior
of Ansible has probably changed, as failed is always in the
result dictionary - just with the value "false". Tested
with Ansible 2.5.11.

Change-Id: Idfa2f33dd6641031ea8a287d74b6dbbfa578c9ab
(cherry picked from commit a2dd79f8b100384ea83c7835688a5795eea90ba6)

commit_message:
Move group_vars for switches group to all group

There are various playbook group variables used to configure switches,
defined in files in ansible/group_vars/switches/. In Ansible 2.3
it was possible to override these via inventory group variables.
In Ansible 2.4+ this is no longer possible, and inventory group
variables have a lower precedence than playbook group variables.

To resolve this, this change moves the switch configuration defaults to
the all group, as is done for other global defaults. The slight downside
is that these variables enter the namespace of every host, but there
aren't too many of them so it shouldn't be a problem.

Change-Id: I1a580a7b88a3e088aa7d5129290427320401f46b
Story: 2004278
Task: 27827
(cherry picked from commit a0bd6320a4ec1acd06e2f28839db96b65e2b444a)

commit_message:
doc: Add solution to live migration ssh issues

This took me a good hour to suss and while there were a couple of Google
hits for it, the top suggestion was to use TCP (rather than SSH) and
disable all security, which is rarely good advice.

Paste an sample error and link to the doc where you can find advice of
resolving the issue.

Change-Id: I3805361834f7d954ae6759a22f61f02db139bcc5
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Seed hypervisor user bootstrapping skipped

Although the 'kayobe seed hypervisor host configure' command executes
the kayobe-ansible-user.yml playbook correctly, the playbook does not
have the seed-hypervisor group in its host list, so it is a noop. This
change fixes that.

Change-Id: I30a83a9851345ece061413d3c1751112247425ae
Story: 2004401
Task: 28034
(cherry picked from commit 5f791a4b46ddf15c35770af4df58139f15a8c9cf)

subject: Fix use of --ask-vault-pass argument
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-21 15:56:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix use of --ask-vault-pass argument

Currently, this argument does not work correctly, since the vault
password is not passed to kayobe via $KAYOBE_VAULT_PASSWORD, meaning
that it cannot update the kolla-ansible passwords.yml file.

It also works non-optimally, since every invocation of ansible-playbook
will prompt for a password.

This change fixes the issue by prompting for a password once in the
kayobe CLI, and storing the password in the $KAYOBE_VAULT_PASSWORD
environment variable. The kayobe-vault-password-helper command is then
used as the --vault-password-file to ansible-playbook, and the helper
pulls the password out of the environment.

Change-Id: I88b1b7b9e9be15b52e730d353ce1b1a6feacceb8
Story: 2001664
Task: 27009
(cherry picked from commit 358b5c68828e6e7de8bfc7654c7418c02380052b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix use of --ask-vault-pass argument

Currently, this argument does not work correctly, since the vault
password is not passed to kayobe via $KAYOBE_VAULT_PASSWORD, meaning
that it cannot update the kolla-ansible passwords.yml file.

It also works non-optimally, since every invocation of ansible-playbook
will prompt for a password.

This change fixes the issue by prompting for a password once in the
kayobe CLI, and storing the password in the $KAYOBE_VAULT_PASSWORD
environment variable. The kayobe-vault-password-helper command is then
used as the --vault-password-file to ansible-playbook, and the helper
pulls the password out of the environment.

Change-Id: I88b1b7b9e9be15b52e730d353ce1b1a6feacceb8
Story: 2001664
Task: 27009
(cherry picked from commit 358b5c68828e6e7de8bfc7654c7418c02380052b)

Kevin you can make that change here and I'll amend the spec in parallel since the latter is just paperwork."}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2019-01-28 08:28:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Sounds like there is general agreement to change the image property
 > and flavor extra spec to be an enum (string field with a single
 > possible value). Kevin you can make that change here and I'll amend
 > the spec in parallel since the latter is just paperwork.

Seems there is some more discussion in the mailling list and yet no conclusion? Maybe I could wait one more day to see what will be the final disicion?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-28 19:49:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Seems there is some more discussion in the mailling list and yet no conclusion? Maybe I could wait one more day to see what will be the final disicion?

Yeah honestly at this point I'm not sure. Now it sounds like Stephen and Jay want to avoid the new image property, extra spec and config option choice and just always set the serial to the instance uuid and deprecate the libvirt.sysinfo_serial config option. I'm not sure what impact that has on existing deployments but it also doesn't seem like a ton of thought was put into the sysinfo_serial option when it was introduced beyond wanting something in the guest to be able to correlate guests on the same host, but we have the hostId parameter for figuring that out (for guests within the same project on the same host)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-29 16:03:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I've added this to the 'stuck review' section of the nova meeting agenda for this week:

https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/Nova#Agenda_for_next_meeting"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-31 15:02:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Here is my summary in the ML:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/002267.html'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2019-02-01 09:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-02-01 14:48:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-02-01 14:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-01 15:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Note that the original suggestion for this when it was a specless blueprint was just a new choice to the sysinfo_serial config option, but that blew up a bit over concerns in the nova meeting when the blueprint was looking for approval:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2018/nova.2018-10-18-14.00.log.html#l-199

And now it seems we've come full circle on this.

The point of the flavor extra spec and image property were for users that really needed the unique serial to be able to get that regardless of the underlying config, which most operators likely don't even know this exists, and making sure that setting "travels" with the instance if it's migrated. In a public cloud, the flavor/image are probably controlled by the operator anyway, so having said that, if we don't have the defined spec/image property, you could still control this with aggregates if needed, i.e. default unique everywhere, restrict via flavor extra spec and aggregate to hosts configured with host serial if needed.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-02-01 15:14:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2019-02-02 01:53:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-26 03:50:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP per instance serial

Change-Id: I001beb2840496f7950988acc69018244847aa888
'}, {'created': '2018-11-26 07:21:32.000000000', 'message': 'Per-instance serial number

A new flavor extra spec ``hw:unique_serial`` and corresponding
image property ``hw_unique_serial`` will be introduced which
when either is set to ``True`` will result in the guest serial
number being set to the instance UUID.

If not set, the serial number in the guest will be based on the
``[libvirt]/sysinfo_serial`` configuration like it is currently.

Implements: blueprint per-instance-libvirt-sysinfo-serial

Change-Id: I001beb2840496f7950988acc69018244847aa888
'}, {'created': '2018-11-28 07:17:59.000000000', 'message': 'Per-instance serial number

commit_message:
Per-instance serial number

Added a new ``unique`` choice to the ``[libvirt]/sysinfo_serial``
configuration which if set will result in the guest serial number
being set to ``instance.uuid`` on this host. It is also made to be
the default value of ``[libvirt]/sysinfo_serial`` config option.

Implements: blueprint per-instance-libvirt-sysinfo-serial

Change-Id: I001beb2840496f7950988acc69018244847aa888

commit_message:
Disable stack check and cancel update for undercloud

'overcloud update abort' command had been dropped since few
releases. However, users can still use heat commands to cancel
an update which is not recommended.

Undercloud now uses heat convergence architecture and stack check
has not been migrated to convergence yet.

let's add heat policy to disable both on undercloud.

Change-Id: Ib5e2dab1e94810ac02e5d64859d2e84f749f3994

commit_message:
Add RoleCtlplanePortMap output

This outputs the ctlplane port ID in both the normal and deployed server
case, so we can discover the ID of the port that should be attached
when creating servers via ironic instead of nova.

Partially-Implements: blueprint nova-less-deploy
Change-Id: Ibb2d19c5db74817102fd49ab9b01fe2d90e49d39

subject: Enable decoupled deployment plans e.g for OpenShift, DPDK etc
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 4328, 'name': 'Steven Hardy', 'email': 'shardy@redhat.com', 'username': 'shardy'}, {'_account_id': 6796, 'name': 'Giulio Fidente', 'email': 'gfidente@redhat.com', 'username': 'gfidente'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 7509, 'name': 'Jiri Tomasek', 'email': 'jtomasek@redhat.com', 'username': 'jtomasek'}, {'_account_id': 8449, 'name': 'Marios Andreou', 'email': 'marios@redhat.com', 'username': 'marios'}, {'_account_id': 8871, 'name': 'Elastic Recheck', 'username': 'elasticrecheck'}, {'_account_id': 11085, 'name': 'Toure Dunnon', 'email': 'toure@redhat.com', 'username': 'Toure'}, {'_account_id': 13039, 'name': 'Martin André', 'email': 'm.andre@redhat.com', 'username': 'mandre'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 18002, 'name': 'John Fulton', 'email': 'fulton@redhat.com', 'username': 'fultonj'}, {'_account_id': 18575, 'name': 'Saravanan KR', 'email': 'krsacme@gmail.com', 'username': 'saravanankr'}, {'_account_id': 21129, 'name': 'Alan Bishop', 'email': 'abishop@redhat.com', 'username': 'ASBishop'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23811, 'name': 'Oliver Walsh', 'email': 'owalsh@redhat.com', 'username': 'owalsh'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:56:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-12 14:59:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

WIP just posted initial ideas for discussion'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:35:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like the split of base environment and openstack specific services environment.

From reading the IRC discussion, I think that the goal should be that we have a deployment_plans directory (curretly plan-samples) where all different plan definitions are defined. Plan definition consists of plan-environment.yaml, capabilities-map.yaml, (maybe more). Default 'OpenStack' plan definition should be included there too. When plan is created (via workflow) the plan definition files are moved into a root of swift container, therefore paths there should reflect that.

I think all environment files can live in common environments directory since we have capabilities-map.yaml which defines which are useable in specific plan. We could leverage this further and just create the swift objects from files listed in capabilities-map.yaml when plan is created.

When I think about it, It may be worth considering if we should move the deployment_plans definitions into a separate repository which would be used to populate separate swift container, from where we would read available deployment plans via a workflow. otherwise, we would have no means to bring up that list via a workflow before plan is created.

With this approach it seems to me that we would not need any specific keys for capabilities-map.yaml (or roles-data.yaml or network-data.yaml) in plan-environment.yaml."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:36:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:44:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> When I think about it, It may be worth considering if we should move the deployment_plans definitions into a separate repository

This is something I was hoping to avoid, but I see that for the UI there's something of a chicken/egg problem where you need to load the plan to get access to the plan samples.

Intially perhaps we can have a workflow to expose the samples available for a given plan, but I guess in the non-default plan case we'll need to copy a bunch of files in order to do that, and it'd be nice to avoid doing that twice.

Maybe the plan creation steps could be e.g:

1. Define plan name
2. Create "draft" plan, either from defaults or from tarball/git etc
3. Offer options of deployment plan samples/architectures
4. Expose roles & configuration based on (3)
5. Validate, deploy etc

It seems we're already doing most of this except (2) which is just copying the plan data earlier?

I think this is related to how we handle modifying the default plan, e.g an operator wants to pass a couple of modified files etc so maybe we can think of that at the same time, e.g how do we create a draft plan then PATCH update it with subsequent changes?'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-12 15:44:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-13 07:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Maybe the plan creation steps could be e.g:
 > 
 > 1. Define plan name
 > 2. Create "draft" plan, either from defaults or from tarball/git
 > etc

Yeah, I think this could work. So from the GUI point of view, plan creation would be 2 step wizard:

In first step, user would provide the source of files (default - user/share/..., git repo, tarball, directory of files -> all these are already supported). Then those plan files would get uploaded.

In the second step, user is allowed to select from predefined 'architectures' loaded from files and specify deployment plan name (preconfigured in plan-environment.yaml).

Important observations:
1. deployment_plans (plan-samples) directory also includes 'OpenStack' deployment plan which is default and is already copied to the root plan-environment.yaml and capabilities-map.yaml. This ensures that when user quits plan creation wizard in step 1, he does not end up in semi-created plan.

2. workflow which is run in second step takes plan name and deployment_type path as input and:
- copies plan-environment.yaml and capabilities-map.yaml (and others) from selected path to root directory overwriting current ones there and updates deployment plan name in plan-environment.yaml

3. user is able to change the plan type at any point of time by editing the plan, although it resets the plan configuration.

4. we remove the functionality of showing 'Other' section of deployment configuration which lists all environments which are not listed in capabilities-map.yaml from tripleo-common. Instead, we create a 'Custom' section which lists user provided environment files from environments/custom
where environments such as user-environment.yaml would be expected to live.

From CLI point of view, user could specify the plan type as an argument when plan is created since CLI user has the files available locally. e.g. -p deployment_plans/openshift'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-13 08:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> 3. user is able to change the plan type at any point of time by editing the plan, although it resets the plan configuration.

Thanks for the feedback - I agree with all of it except this one - do we want to allow changing plan deployment type, particularly after deployment has happened?

My worry is this could be really destructive if done by accident so probably should be prevented by default?'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-13 08:57:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> do we want to allow changing plan deployment type, particularly
 > after deployment has happened?
 > 
 > My worry is this could be really destructive if done by accident so
 > probably should be prevented by default?

You're right, I agree."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-13 09:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-13 10:59:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-13 15:23:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-13 15:25:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-13 15:26:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

For now I need to switch the plan-samples directory name back as it's breaking packaging/CI by renaming it.  We can rename it later if needed."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-14 08:33:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-14 10:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-14 11:31:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

The symlinked plan-environment broke CI so I've made copies for now, testing locally to see if that's easily fixable."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-18 10:34:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Ok so the swift bulk upload doesn't handle symlinks in the tarball, so for now I think we'll have to copy the files - I'll add a note to the README and a validation to keep them in sync"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-18 11:18:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-18 11:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-18 13:55:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-18 14:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-18 14:55:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-19 10:35:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-19 14:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Ok one question after some testing - Is it reasonable to regnerate the default roles_data.yaml when a plan_environment.yaml contains role_tags?  

I think we probably have to as if you select e.g plan-samples/openshift/plan-environment.yaml we end up pointing to the openstack roles which no longer work as the services are undefined.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-06-19 17:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-06-19 20:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode: unrecognized error
- tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1686542

- tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario007-multinode-oooq-container: unrecognized error
- tripleo-ci-centos-7-undercloud-oooq: unrecognized error

Some of the tests failed in a way that we did not understand. Please help us classify these issues so that they can be part of Elastic Recheck http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-20 10:06:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-20 10:08:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-06-20 12:24:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

- tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode: https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1686542

If you believe we've correctly identified the failure, feel free to leave a 'recheck' comment to run the tests again.
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/"}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-06-21 09:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-21 13:39:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-06-21 14:08:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

> Ok one question after some testing - Is it reasonable to regnerate
 > the default roles_data.yaml when a plan_environment.yaml contains
 > role_tags?
 > 
 > I think we probably have to as if you select e.g plan-samples/openshift/plan-environment.yaml
 > we end up pointing to the openstack roles which no longer work as
 > the services are undefined.

+1, problem is that default roles for the plan type are not defined anywhere. When user selects plan type, we should look at roles_data.yaml and update it so it includes only roles which are produced by list_available_roles workflow (filtered by tags).

I believe there should already be such logic in select_roles workflow. User passes a list of role names to select_roles, it should generate roles_data.yaml which will consist of roles which are listed by list_available_roles workflow.

IIRC select_roles workflow currently throws error in this case, we should probably change that logic.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-21 15:46:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-06-21 16:42:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-06-26 07:29:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

I really support this great idea and would love to see it even this late in Rocky. Basically, just a refactoring w/o major changes to DF'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-04 13:53:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-04 13:53:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Workflow-1

WIP as I need to implement copying the default plan for the undercloud deploy, since it won't use the mistral workflow linked in the Depends-On"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-07-05 20:44:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I like this and I only did a -1 because I want a small change with the proposed rename of derived parameters (details below). Also I have some questions below on how Ceph would move into this new pattern and how it would work with the HCI derived parameters deployment plan. I just want to make sure we have a way to support them with what's proposed here and then I'd be happy to + vote. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-07-05 20:50:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-11 13:33:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Thanks for the review John, happy to make the changes you requested, but some comments/context added.

One of my aims with this was to support the ceph standalone case, so it's important we get patterns in place that will support that, thanks for the feedback!"}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-07-12 17:02:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: -Code-Review

http://logs.openstack.org/53/574753/21/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario000-multinode-oooq-container-updates/516a10d/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/overcloud_update_prepare.log.txt.gz looks genuine:

WorkflowServiceError: Exception updating plan: Error retrieving environment for plan overcloud: Object GET failed: http://192.168.24.1:8080/v1/AUTH_0b39e2fc1663472f9b045854a4770f83/overcloud/plan-environment.yaml 404'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-18 16:01:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21: Workflow-1

Yeah the updates CI failure looks real but I've not yet figured out why - we should persist the plan-environment when updating the plan for the overcloud update but it seems that we aren't - I need to reproduce locally to debug"}, {'account_id': 11085, 'date': '2018-07-19 13:48:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

So I see that you deleted the plan-environment.yaml but I don't see a replacement, as the README states this is a mandatory file, am I missing something, just curious."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-19 15:11:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

> So I see that you deleted the plan-environment.yaml but I don't see a replacement, as the README states this is a mandatory file, am I missing something, just curious.

There's now a tripleo-common workflow that selects a plan-environment.yaml from the plan-samples directory:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579892/"}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-19 15:14:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 21:

Ok so I figured out the update failure with some help from d0ugal, the issue is tripleoclient empties the entire plan container, including any plan-environment.yaml, every update.

This is really a bug in the client, albeit a longstanding one, as although we recreate it I'm not sure all user plan-environment.yaml content would be regenerated in a non-lossy way.

Probably we need to change the client behavior so plan-environment.yaml and capabilities-map.yaml aren't purged on plan update and/or handle the update plan via a workflow so the client container purge isn't required - I'll look into that tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-27 14:50:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2018-07-27 15:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

Ok to work around the update/upgrade issues I reinstated the default plan-environment.yaml but that will mean users need to copy plan-samples/* instead of the workflows I added.

That still means that -p needs to be specified every update (which is probably a bug in the current implementation but this doesn't make it any worse), and we need some way to persist the alternate capabilities-map over updates."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2019-02-11 09:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

between the "core" tripleo deployment interfaces, and the OpenStack
specific services which are deployed by default.

commit_message:
Enable decoupled deployment plans e.g for OpenShift, DPDK etc

This is exploring how we might pass a different -p option to the
various CLI's that accept it, such that for example we can create
a plan which only deals with OpenShift without the default OpenStack
services and associated configuration options.

The same pattern could potentially be applied to other applications
e.g ceph, and as in this patch specific OpenStack configurations
such as DPDK.

Change-Id: I991e30b1debadfa76f1fffb80bd9e5798b6cd527

parameter_merge_strategies.

wow, its quite a change. I am trying to figure out how the order of the environment files is maintained. If we update all env files (provided as -e) to swift container as a seprate file, does the order stays as is, like the last included parameters take the precedence?'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-27 16:44:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Note I've started breaking this into a series of patches ref https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:open+project:openstack/python-tripleoclient+branch:master+topic:bug/1635409

Re the environment file ordering, that will be maintained by the ordering of the list of environments in the mistral environment I think (and, in future the order of the plan-environment.yaml file which contains a list of environments).

I tried to find a simpler way to solve this bug, but unfortunately I couldn't, so yes it has ended up being a pretty large and invasive change, hopefully the smaller patches will help."}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:20:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:20:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:22:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:27:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:32:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2017-03-29 15:42:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-03-29 16:06:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Verified-1

before we can push forward this, we'll need to make sure that this heat bug is fixed:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1669571

for which there is a patch from therve:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/461904/

but essentially, the server side parameter handling in heat would not work for how TripleO layers environments with a specified order."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2017-11-30 08:05:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

After merging this, we'll also need to update https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-common/blob/master/tripleo_common/actions/heat_capabilities.py#L30 action which is used to list environments according to capabilities map.

Currently, the environments not listed in capabilities map but present in <plan>/environments are appended under 'Other' topic.

We need to do the same to environments in <plan>/user-environments. Probably under 'Custom Environments' topic."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 01:22:40.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-01-25 23:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-07-03 11:45:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-07-03 11:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)

A naive rebase attempt from me. We need to reinspect the code to be in parity with the new changes for the last 5 months...'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2019-02-11 09:59:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-03-21 17:36:44.000000000', 'message': "Don't merge environments during plan creation

Currently we merge all environment files locally, which means
we can't take advantage of the heat environment merging
features, which require a list of environment files to be
passed to the heat API, then the merging happens on the
server side.

This requires some significant rework, as we need to upload
each individual environment file to swift (added under the
user-environments path), and rewrite all paths to match
the new location in the swift container.

Partial-Bug: #1635409
Change-Id: I0ffad373937414ce3894bc89fbe6df8388cebb27

commit_message:
Don't merge environments during plan creation

Currently we merge all environment files locally, which means
we can't take advantage of the heat environment merging
features, which require a list of environment files to be
passed to the heat API, then the merging happens on the
server side.

This requires some significant rework, as we need to upload
each individual environment file to swift (added under the
user-environments path), and rewrite all paths to match
the new location in the swift container.

Partial-Bug: #1635409
Change-Id: I0ffad373937414ce3894bc89fbe6df8388cebb27
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move developer docs to its own top-level section

Developer docs shouldn't be under Install Guide. This patch moves
developer docs from Install Guide to its own top-level section and
updates any internal broken links accordingly.

It's worth noting that this move will break external URLs which have
pointed to developer docs until now. I think the change is still worth
it to bring more clarity both to the internal docs structure and to
the docs landing page -- separating the dev docs for more visibility
in both. This will also generate a "Developer Guide" link to the main
documentation sidebar automatically.

I considered using symlinks to keep the old external links alive, but
that would break relative internal content links, so this situation
does not seem to be easily unsolvable.

Minor changes included:

* Since we're already breaking URLs, change the names of the
  subcontent index pages:

  developer/developer to developer/index
  developer/upgrade/upgrade to developer/upgrade/index
  developer/tht_walkthrough/tht_walkthrough to developer/tht_walkthrough/index

* Rename and capitalize headings for Upgrade, THT walkthrough and
  Mistral dev docs to make the generated index nicer.

Change-Id: I639c5583b7b355f4b7c6ca5550f778d14f8fcd21

commit_message:
Added ssh configuration for stack user on the undercloud

The issue is mainly related to dev: when you connect to the undercloud,
you don't really want to have to pass "heat-admin@" or "-l heat-admin"
when you connect to the overcloud nodes.

Of course, you can connect from your quickstart node, but when you work
directly on the undercloud, you don't have the facilities the generated
ssh-config file in your quickstart directory provides.

This simple patch just workaround these issues and allow to work in a
more convenient way directly from the undercloud node.

The SSH host key aren't accepted by default. Following a discussion,
accepting them automatically might hide some future issues, as the
host keys will be added automatically.

Change-Id: I7eb27541a72b0bc1c87bfb3ebfcd7c8c43ecb47f

commit_message:
Support to filter resources by tags

Add 'tags', 'tags-any', 'not-tags', 'not-tags-any' param keys for
resource query.

Doc reference:
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/tags.html#filtering-and-searching-by-tags

Change-Id: Ie752aa8e744d54c4909b97876dee450293d29908
Story: 2004810
Task: 28970

commit_message:
Fixing container-build job

When the base zuul job moved from openstack-infra to
opendev the role openstack-zuul-jobs which we depend
on for the swap was removed.

This patch manually imports that repo.

Change-Id: I90acaf010014664879f5c0d2f1a1ef660baf498f

commit_message:
Reject unshelve with port having resource request

Nova does not consider the resource request of a Neutron port as of now.
So this patch makes sure that server unshelve request on servers that
was offload is rejected if it involves a port that has resource request.
When the feature is ready on the nova side this limitation will be lifted.

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I5a956513f3485074023e027430cc52ee7a3f92e4

commit_message:
Reject migrate with port having resource request

Nova does not consider the resource request of a Neutron port as of now.
So this patch makes sure that server migrate and live migrate requests are
rejected if they involve a port that has resource request. When the feature
is ready on the nova side this limitation will be lifted.

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I48e6db9693e470b177bf4c75211d8b883c768433

commit_message:
Turn off rp association refresh in nova-next

Set [compute]resource_provider_association_refresh=0 to turn off all
periodic refreshing of the provider cache in the report client.

Note that this probably will have zero effect in the nova-next job
other than making sure that that setting doesn't blow up the world.
Because the job is always doing something, there's never a lull long
enough for the refresh timers to expire anyway, so no periodic
refreshing was happening even before this change.

Change-Id: I072b3fa4847db14e5a3f03c775a377e3514224f1

commit_message:
Ignore SAWarnings for "Evaluating non-mapped column expression"

These warnings come from oslo.db code (tracked with bug 1814199)
so there isn't much nova can do about that right now, outside of
monkey patching oslo.db which is a bad idea.

Let's ignore the warning until the bug in oslo.db is fixed to
avoid blowing up our unit/functional test console output logs
which in turn is intermittently triggering subunit.parser failures.

Change-Id: Ifdfeadae8b348d788de2cd665544015366271d66
Related-Bug: #1813147

This patch switches tempest-slow to new
tempest-slow-py3 job.

For coverage of tempest-slow tests on py2,
Tempest check pipeline will continue running
this job on check pipeline. As this tempest-slow
job is not from integrated gate template, it is
ok to run only py3 job on project side.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/633983
Change-Id: I614dea09547c8f86f667b1daeb18f69fea7937fb
'}]
commit_message:
Switch tempest-slow to be run on python 3

This patch switches tempest-slow to new
tempest-slow-py3 job.

For coverage of tempest-slow tests on py2,
Tempest check pipeline will continue running
this job on check pipeline. As this tempest-slow
job is not from integrated gate template, it is
ok to run only py3 job on project side.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/633983
Change-Id: I614dea09547c8f86f667b1daeb18f69fea7937fb

commit_message:
PCI: do not force remove allocated devices

In the ocata release the pci_passthrough_whitelist
was moved from the [DEFAULT] section of the nova.conf
to the [pci] section and renamed to passthrough_whitelist.

On upgrading if the operator chooses to migrate the config
value to the new section it is not uncommon
to forget to rename the config value.
Similarly if an operator is updateing the whitelist and
mistypes the value it can also lead to the whitelist
being ignored.

As a result of either error the nova compute agent
would delete all database entries for a host regardless of
if the pci device was in use by an instance. If this occurs
the only recorse for an operator is to delete and recreate
the guest on that host after correcting the error or manually
restore the database to backup or otherwise consistent state.

This change alters the _set_hvdevs function to not force
remove allocated or claimed devices if they are no longer
present in the pci whitelist.

Closes-Bug: #1633120
Change-Id: I6e871311a0fa10beaf601ca6912b4a33ba4094e0

commit_message:
Add logstash ingestion for collectd

This change will allow logstash to ingest metrics from collectd. New
options have been added to enable the deployment and configure it.

Change-Id: I995c0db69fc68d5f5bcae27ce16956876368e2a8
Signed-off-by: cloudnull <kevin@cloudnull.com>

It was noted [1] that we don't need to wrap all of _update in a retry on
ResourceProviderUpdateConflict; only _update_to_placement can raise that
exception, and that exception only indicates a need to redrive with data
ret-GETted from within that method. So this patch moves the retry
decorator further in, to _update_to_placement, to avoid the additional
redundant compute node and pci tracker writes.

WIP: fix tests

commit_message:
Move retry from _update to _update_to_placement

It was noted [1] that we don't need to wrap all of _update in a retry on
ResourceProviderUpdateConflict; only _update_to_placement can raise that
exception, and that exception only indicates a need to redrive with data
ret-GETted from within that method. So this patch moves the retry
decorator further in, to _update_to_placement, to avoid the additional
redundant compute node and pci tracker writes.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615705/20/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py@974

Change-Id: I85e567181cdeefde0a9ef91cd460cd200e79bdba

commit_message:
Read port resource request from Neutron

This patch collects the resource requests from each neutron port
involved in a server create request. Converts each request to
a RequestGroup object.

blueprint bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I4473cb192447b5bfa9d1dfcc0dd5216c536caf73

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-04 11:32:30.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Add support for vrouter HW offloads

Add plumbing for Contrail/Tungsten Fabric offloads

* This change expands the VNIC type support for the vrouter VIF type by
  adding 'direct' and 'virtio-forwarder' plugging support.

* After this change, the vrouter VIF type will support the following four
  modes:
  * 'normal': the 'classic' tap-style VNIC plugged into the instance,
  * 'normal' with vhostuser: a dpdk-vhostuser VNIC plugged into the
    instance,
  * 'direct': a PCI Virtual Function is passed through to the instance,
  * 'virtio-forwarder': a PCI Virtual Function is proxied to the
    instance via a vhost-user virtio forwarder.

* The OS-VIF conversion function was extended to support the two new
  plugging modes.

* Unit tests were added for the OS-VIF conversion functions.

* TODO: The vrouter VIF unit test cases need to be extended.

* The corresponding review on OpenContrail is currently at:
  https://review.opencontrail.org/#/c/42850/

Change-Id: I327894839a892a976cf314d4292b22ce247b0afa
Depends-On: I401ee6370dad68e62bc2d089e786a840d91d0267
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>

commit_message:
Add support for vrouter HW datapath offloads

Add plumbing for Contrail/Tungsten Fabric datapath offloads

* This change expands the VNIC type support for the vrouter VIF type by
  adding 'direct' and 'virtio-forwarder' plugging support.

* After this change, the vrouter VIF type will support the following modes:
  * 'normal': the 'classic' tap-style VNIC plugged into the instance,
  * 'direct': a PCI Virtual Function is passed through to the instance,
  * 'virtio-forwarder': a PCI Virtual Function is proxied to the
    instance via a vhost-user virtio forwarder.

* The os-vif conversion function was extended to support the two new
  plugging modes.

* Unit tests were added for the os-vif conversion functions.

* OpenContrail / Tungsten Fabric is planning to consume this
  functionality for the 5.1 release.

* os-vif 1.14.0 is required to pass the metadata

Change-Id: I327894839a892a976cf314d4292b22ce247b0afa
Depends-On: I401ee6370dad68e62bc2d089e786a840d91d0267
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: vrouter-hw-offloads

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-05 16:29:51.000000000', 'message': "Set ETCD_USE_RAMDISK=True by default

Cinder and etcd are enabled by default and by default
cinder uses etcd as a distributed lock manager with
tooz as an intermediary. We see a lot of ToozConnectionErrors [1]
in the cinder logs when etcd is backed up [2] which results in
cinder operations timing out causing test failures, like
when a volume is not deleted within a given time.

This changes ETCD_USE_RAMDISK=True by default to try and
alleviate some of the pressure. An alternative is if we know
we're in a single-node job we could just not use a DLM for
Cinder.

[1] http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/#1810526
[2] etcd[26824]: sync duration of 12.076762123s, expected less than 1s

Change-Id: I5f82aa40e9d84114e7b7b5cf19ec4942d6552490
Partial-Bug: #1810526
"}]
commit_message:
Set ETCD_USE_RAMDISK=True by default

Cinder and etcd are enabled by default and by default
cinder uses etcd as a distributed lock manager with
tooz as an intermediary. We see a lot of ToozConnectionErrors [1]
in the cinder logs when etcd is backed up [2] which results in
cinder operations timing out causing test failures, like
when a volume is not deleted within a given time.

This changes ETCD_USE_RAMDISK=True by default to try and
alleviate some of the pressure. An alternative is if we know
we're in a single-node job we could just not use a DLM for
Cinder.

[1] http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/#1810526
[2] etcd[26824]: sync duration of 12.076762123s, expected less than 1s

Change-Id: I5f82aa40e9d84114e7b7b5cf19ec4942d6552490
Partial-Bug: #1810526

devices allowed to attach to a single instance.

current behavior of returning a 500 to the user.

The server create API returns a 500 error to the user because any
failure that occurs during instance build in nova-compute will raise
a BuildAbortException, which is treated as a 500.

Part of blueprint conf-max-attach-volumes

Change-Id: Ia9cc1c250483c31f44cdbba4f6342ac8d7fbe92b
'}, {'created': '2019-01-24 03:26:09.000000000', 'message': 'Add configuration of maximum disk devices to attach

This adds a new config option to control the maximum number of disk
devices allowed to attach to a single instance, which can be set per
compute host.

The configured maximum is enforced when device names are generated
during server create, rebuild, evacuate, unshelve, live migrate, and
attach volume. When the maximum is exceeded during server create,
rebuild, evacuate, unshelve, or live migrate, the server will go into
ERROR state and the server fault will contain the reason. When the
maximum is exceeded during an attach volume request, the request fails
fast in the API with a 403 error.

The configured maximum on the destination is not enforced before cold
migrate because the maximum is enforced in-place only (the destination
is not checked over RPC). The configured maximum is also not enforced
on shelved offloaded servers because they have no compute host, and the
option is implemented at the nova-compute level.

Part of blueprint conf-max-attach-volumes

Change-Id: Ia9cc1c250483c31f44cdbba4f6342ac8d7fbe92b

commit_message:
Add configuration of maximum disk devices to attach

This adds a new config option to control the maximum number of disk
devices allowed to attach to a single instance, which can be set per
compute host.

The configured maximum is enforced when device names are generated
during server create, rebuild, evacuate, unshelve, live migrate, and
attach volume. When the maximum is exceeded during server create,
rebuild, evacuate, unshelve, or live migrate, the server will go into
ERROR state and the server fault will contain the reason. When the
maximum is exceeded during an attach volume request, the request fails
fast in the API with a 403 error.

The configured maximum on the destination is not enforced before cold
migrate because the maximum is enforced in-place only (the destination
is not checked over RPC). The configured maximum is also not enforced
on shelved offloaded servers because they have no compute host, and the
option is implemented at the nova-compute level.

Part of blueprint conf-max-attach-volumes

Change-Id: Ia9cc1c250483c31f44cdbba4f6342ac8d7fbe92b

commit_message:
Make 'plugin' a required argument for '_get_vif_instance'

'plugin' is the one argument for 'os_vif.objects.vif.VIFBase' (and
therefore all subclasses) that doesn't have a default and is therefore
required [1]. Enforce this on the nova side and prevent possible slip
ups like those seen in [2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/os-vif/blob/1.11.1/os_vif/objects/vif.py#L27-L52
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/565471/4/nova/network/os_vif_util.py@408

Change-Id: I9598008deff92fae704786b467ef622848f55cf9
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Collect duplicate codepaths in os_vif_util

This change collects a number of associated codepaths into helper
functions. The following steps have been broken out into functions:

* Creating an os-vif instance for VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT VIFs.
* Creating an os-vif port profile for ovs representor datapath offloads
* Populating representor datapath offloads metadata in a VIF's port profile

This commit also harmonises indentation style a bit in the agilio_ovs
and vrouter conversion functions.

Change-Id: Id28858b623812812f14eabd38113990a3daec387
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: generic-os-vif-offloads

commit_message:
Duplicate os-vif datapath offload metadata

This patch duplicates the datapath offload metadata for the openvswitch
and agilio_ovs os-vif plugins. The aim is to transition to the
composed interface rather than the inherited class, while still
providing overlap for at least one release cycle.

Change-Id: I1cb58292896642e557e8257c42b2713aed06fc37
Depends-On: I401ee6370dad68e62bc2d089e786a840d91d0267
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: generic-os-vif-offloads

(7 comments)

Main issue has to do with the fact that when the port creation fails during server create in the nova-compute service, we've already responded with a 202 to the user. I think there is something wrong with the functional test for that (is it using the CastAsCall fixture?) and _build_and_run_instance is not handling the new type of exception which means we'll reschedule to another compute host which will just fail for the same thing - we should handle the new exception in _build_and_run_instance and raise BuildAbortException."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-24 19:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-24 19:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

[{'created': '2018-05-22 23:32:17.000000000', 'message': 'Reject networks with QoS policy

When nova needs to create ports in neutron in a network that has minimum
bandwidth policy nova would need to create allocation for the bandwidth
resources. The port creation happens in the compute manager after the
scheduling and resource claiming. Supporting this considered out of
scope for the first iteration of this feature.

To avoid resource allocation inconsistencies this patch propose to
reject such request.

Change-Id: I7e1edede827cf8469771c0496b1dce55c627cf5d

When nova needs to create ports in Neutron in a network that has minimum
bandwidth policy Nova would need to create allocation for the bandwidth
resources. The port creation happens in the compute manager after the
scheduling and resource claiming. Supporting for this is considered out
of scope for the first iteration of this feature.

reject such request. This rejection does not break any existing as
minimum bandwidth policy rule only supported by the SRIOV Neutron

are precreated in Neutron.

commit_message:
Reject networks with QoS policy

When nova needs to create ports in Neutron in a network that has minimum
bandwidth policy Nova would need to create allocation for the bandwidth
resources. The port creation happens in the compute manager after the
scheduling and resource claiming. Supporting for this is considered out
of scope for the first iteration of this feature.

To avoid resource allocation inconsistencies this patch propose to
reject such request. This rejection does not break any existing use
case as minimum bandwidth policy rule only supported by the SRIOV
Neutron backend but Nova only support booting with SRIOV port if those
ports are precreated in Neutron.

Co-Authored-By: Elod Illes <elod.illes@ericsson.com>

Change-Id: I7e1edede827cf8469771c0496b1dce55c627cf5d
blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

commit_message:
Create RequestGroup from neutron port

This patch adds a factory method for the RequestGroup ovo that
constructs an object based on the resource request in a neutron port.

blueprint bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: Id3813d8b064f0981b51c9ffbb90fc819e9617e42

commit_message:
Consolidate inventory refresh

get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root now refreshes inventories via the
_ensure_resource_provider code path, so the call to
_refresh_and_get_inventories in get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root is no
longer necessary.

Change-Id: Iece924e85409bd4d9cd38ce6ced7883ffc905310

commit_message:
Include requested_resources to allocation candidate query

The RequestSpec.requested_resources now can hold RequestGroup objects
describing extra resources that are needed for this instance. So this
patch makes sure that such RequestGroups are included into the
allocation candidate query.

blueprint bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I7b2718f1a97417693e1176a204d0133f6f5ac098

commit_message:
Fix using template cell urls with nova-manage

When nova-manage went to validate the transport-url given in config or on the
command line, it was not doing the translation before passing the url to the
oslo.messaging parse routine to check it. This exposes the format functions
from the CellMapping object, and makes our _validate_transport_url() format
the url before passing it to parse.

This also adds a test that makes sure the template makes it into the database
(as a template) and that it gets loaded out in translated form with an
object load.

Change-Id: I40a435b8e97c8552c2f5f0ca3a24de2edd9f81bd
Closes-Bug: #1812196

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/571325/10 : FAILURE in 2h 21m 44s'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-29 15:25:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

evacuate failed because vif plugging timed out (timed out waiting to get the network-vif-plugged event from neutron on the dest host during the evacuate):

http://logs.openstack.org/25/571325/10/gate/nova-live-migration/52e1cd0/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz?#_Jan_29_01_16_58_915051'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-29 15:32:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

The API processes the network-vif-plugged for that server here:

http://logs.openstack.org/25/571325/10/gate/nova-live-migration/52e1cd0/logs/screen-n-api.txt.gz#_Jan_29_01_11_49_707004

Jan 29 01:11:49.707004 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 devstack@n-api.service[22319]: DEBUG nova.api.openstack.wsgi [req-3ed0ada1-7328-4d5a-a3ea-da34dcdb252d req-1f5aeede-83c6-44d5-afd4-b5435e71d61f service nova] Action: 'create', calling method: <bound method ServerExternalEventsController.create of <nova.api.openstack.compute.server_external_events.ServerExternalEventsController object at 0x7fb0133aa050>>, body: {"events": [{"status": "completed", "tag": "e241f79f-fb0d-4961-b0c8-aea9de2755bf", "name": "network-vif-plugged", "server_uuid": "2e82ddcd-75b8-4a41-8ecd-ce175adbdc67"}]} {{(pid=22322) _process_stack /opt/stack/new/nova/nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py:520}}

Jan 29 01:11:49.765687 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 devstack@n-api.service[22319]: INFO nova.api.openstack.compute.server_external_events [req-3ed0ada1-7328-4d5a-a3ea-da34dcdb252d req-1f5aeede-83c6-44d5-afd4-b5435e71d61f service nova] Creating event network-vif-plugged:e241f79f-fb0d-4961-b0c8-aea9de2755bf for instance 2e82ddcd-75b8-4a41-8ecd-ce175adbdc67 on ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201758
Jan 29 01:11:49.776578 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 devstack@n-api.service[22319]: DEBUG nova.compute.api [req-3ed0ada1-7328-4d5a-a3ea-da34dcdb252d req-1f5aeede-83c6-44d5-afd4-b5435e71d61f service nova] Instance 2e82ddcd-75b8-4a41-8ecd-ce175adbdc67 is migrating, copying events to all relevant hosts: set([u'ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201758', u'ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755']) {{(pid=22322) _get_relevant_hosts /opt/stack/new/nova/nova/compute/api.py:4818}}
Jan 29 01:11:49.786947 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 devstack@n-api.service[22319]: INFO nova.api.openstack.requestlog [req-3ed0ada1-7328-4d5a-a3ea-da34dcdb252d req-1f5aeede-83c6-44d5-afd4-b5435e71d61f service nova] 10.210.224.40 "POST /compute/v2.1/os-server-external-events" status: 200 len: 183 microversion: 2.1 time: 0.084393

Which is weird because that's before the vif plugging timeout in the compute logs. From the compute logs, we plugged the vif here:

Jan 29 01:11:55.571807 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 nova-compute[15903]: INFO os_vif [None req-252304a1-6eff-4ff3-aa4d-b4e0ab87601c demo admin] Successfully plugged vif VIFOpenVSwitch(active=False,address=fa:16:3e:66:03:76,bridge_name='br-int',has_traffic_filtering=True,id=e241f79f-fb0d-4961-b0c8-aea9de2755bf,network=Network(2812d9e2-bfa8-4397-9a81-5dab9fe5a03e),plugin='ovs',port_profile=VIFPortProfileOpenVSwitch,preserve_on_delete=False,vif_name='tape241f79f-fb')

So it looks like maybe we're getting the network-vif-plugged event before we're ready for it and so we miss the event and then timeout? That's pretty weird though because the libvirt driver's spawn method is what should be registering and waiting for the vif plugged event:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c134feda3d9527dbc9735e4ae9cd35c4782f1fb4/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L5673'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-29 15:40:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Looks like the compute does register the event callback for network-vif-plugged here:

Jan 29 01:11:55.567189 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 nova-compute[15903]: DEBUG nova.compute.manager [None req-252304a1-6eff-4ff3-aa4d-b4e0ab87601c demo admin] [instance: 2e82ddcd-75b8-4a41-8ecd-ce175adbdc67] Preparing to wait for external event network-vif-plugged-e241f79f-fb0d-4961-b0c8-aea9de2755bf {{(pid=15903) prepare_for_instance_event /opt/stack/new/nova/nova/compute/manager.py:325}}

Which is too late:

Jan 29 01:11:49.707004 ubuntu-xenial-rax-ord-0002201755 devstack@n-api.service[22319]: DEBUG nova.api.openstack.wsgi [req-3ed0ada1-7328-4d5a-a3ea-da34dcdb252d req-1f5aeede-83c6-44d5-afd4-b5435e71d61f service nova] Action: 'create', calling method: <bound method ServerExternalEventsController.create of <nova.api.openstack.compute.server_external_events.ServerExternalEventsController object at 0x7fb0133aa050>>, body: {"events": [{"status": "completed", "tag": "e241f79f-fb0d-4961-b0c8-aea9de2755bf", "name": "network-vif-plugged", "server_uuid": "2e82ddcd-75b8-4a41-8ecd-ce175adbdc67"}]} {{(pid=22322) _process_stack /opt/stack/new/nova/nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py:520}}'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-29 15:47:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Reported bug 1813789 for that gate failure.'}, {'account_id': 25733, 'date': '2019-01-30 03:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-01-30 06:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-30 22:21:58.000000000', 'message': 'Convert vrouter legacy plugging to os-vif

Before this change, the vrouter VIF type used legacy VIF plugging. This
changeset ports the plugging methods over to an external os-vif plugin,
simplifying the in-tree code.

Miscellaneous notes:

 * There are two "vrouter" VIF types:
    * "contrail_vrouter" supporting vhostuser plugging, and
    * "vrouter", supporting kernel datapath plugging.
 * This change extends the functionality of the "vrouter"
   VIF type to also support vhostuser plugging, should the Neutron
   plugin wish to unify VIF types.
 * The VIFGeneric os-vif type is used for the kernel TAP based
   plugging.
 * In order to pass the multiqueue hint to the os-vif plugin, os-vif
   needs to be extended with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570959
 * It's possible to pass this hint via the VIF object, but it's a
   lot less invasive to pass it via the instance information.
 * The review for the OpenContrail/Tungsten Fabric side of this work is
   at https://review.opencontrail.org/#/c/43399

Change-Id: I047856982251fddc631679fb2dbcea0f3b0db097
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-05-31 12:37:33.000000000', 'message': 'Convert vrouter legacy plugging to os-vif

commit_message:
Convert vrouter legacy plugging to os-vif

Before this change, the vrouter VIF type used legacy VIF plugging. This
changeset ports the plugging methods over to an external os-vif plugin,
simplifying the in-tree code.

Miscellaneous notes:

 * There are two "vrouter" Neutron VIF types:
    * "contrail_vrouter" supporting vhostuser plugging, and
    * "vrouter", supporting kernel datapath plugging.
 * The VIFGeneric os-vif type is used for the kernel TAP based
   plugging when the vnic_type is 'normal'.
 * For multiqueue support, the minimum version of libvirt 1.3.1 is
   required. In that case, libvirt creates the TAP device, rather than
   the os-vif plugin. (This is the minimum version for Rocky and later)
   ref: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/libvirt/+bug/1574957
 * The corresponding commit on Tungsten Fabric / OpenContrail for this
   work is at:
   https://github.com/Juniper/contrail-nova-vif-driver/commit/ed01d315e5707b4f670468454729dc2031c5f780

Change-Id: I047856982251fddc631679fb2dbcea0f3b0db097
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
blueprint: vrouter-os-vif-conversion

* quote args
* enable iscsid debug
* export full journal

[{'created': '2018-12-13 11:33:54.000000000', 'message': "WIP don't call begin_detaching when detaching volume from sheved vm

WIP, still need to figure out the different behavior between shelve
and resize.

Change-Id: Ib1799feebbd8f4b0f389168939df7e5e90c8add1
closes-bug: #1808089
"}, {'created': '2018-12-21 08:51:22.000000000', 'message': "Don't call begin_detaching when detaching volume from sheved vm

When shelve an instance, if the instance has volume attached,
with new attach/detach flow, we will delete the old attachment
and create a new attachment, the volume status will be ``reserved``
in Cinder side, it will cause error if we call begin_detaching()
as it will check whether the status is ``in-use``.

Acutally for shelved instances, we can just skip this step and
directly detach it.

Change-Id: Ib1799feebbd8f4b0f389168939df7e5e90c8add1
closes-bug: #1808089
"}, {'created': '2018-12-24 03:03:36.000000000', 'message': "Don't call begin_detaching when detaching volume from sheveld vm

When shelve an instance, if the instance has volume attached,
with new attach/detach flow, we will delete the old attachment
and create a new attachment, the volume status will be ``reserved``.

If the user tries to detach these volumes, it fails due to that
Cinder does not allow a begin_detaching() call on a `reserved` volume.

Acutally for shelved instances, we can just skip this step and
directly detach it.

Change-Id: Ib1799feebbd8f4b0f389168939df7e5e90c8add1
closes-bug: #1808089
"}, {'created': '2019-01-21 02:01:01.000000000', 'message': "Don't call begin_detaching when detaching volume from sheveld vm

closes-bug: #1808089

commit_message:
Don't call begin_detaching when detaching volume from shelved vm

When shelve an instance, if the instance has volume attached,
with new attach/detach flow, we will delete the old attachment
and create a new attachment, the volume status will be ``reserved``.

If the user tries to detach these volumes, it fails due to that
Cinder does not allow a begin_detaching() call on a `reserved` volume.

Actually for shelved instances, we can just skip this step and
directly detach it.

Change-Id: Ib1799feebbd8f4b0f389168939df7e5e90c8add1
closes-bug: #1808089

commit_message:
Reject server create with port having resource request

Nova does not consider the resource request of a Neutron port as of now.
So this patch makes sure that server create request is rejected if it
involves a port that has resource request. When the feature is ready on
the nova side this limitation will be lifted.

Change-Id: I97f06d0ec34cbd75c182caaa686b8de5c777a576
blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

subject: Bug #1439568 instructions on README.rst were not working
messages:
[{'account_id': 29823, 'date': '2019-01-19 10:08:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-19 10:08:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-01-30 05:32:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hello sanooj,

I noticed you had submitted your first patch to OpenStack! Congratulations! I just wanted to reach out and follow up with you on the comments on your patch to see if you need any help. We want to help you get your patch merged and help you be successful in our community! 

Please let us know if you have any questions about your patch, the review process, or the community itself. 

I have added a Zaqar dev, Wang Hao, to your patch who can help you along your OpenStack journey!

Hope to hear from you soon, 

Matthew Oliver (mattoliverau) and the rest of the First Contact SIG'}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2019-01-30 06:12:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Hi sanooj, welcome to OpenStack and Zaqar project.  This a very good catch. I have left a comment inline,  you can fix it soon. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 29823, 'date': '2019-01-30 06:48:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Hi sanooj, welcome to OpenStack and Zaqar project.  This a very
 > good catch. I have left a comment inline,  you can fix it soon.
 > Thanks

Thanks Wanghao, I have removed the Whitespace and pushed the changes.https://review.openstack.org/#/c/631920/1 Please review.'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-01-30 07:10:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

great, only thing we need to teach you is how to made new change sets. Each fix shouldn't be a new change. It should appear (and stay apart of this change).

The secret with gerrit is you need to amend the existing change and then re push (git review it up) and you need to make sure the Change-Id in the commit message remains intact. See: https://docs.openstack.org/contributors/code-and-documentation/using-gerrit.html

So in this case, you'd go fix the space, then "git commit -a --amend" to commit the change then "git review". This will appear here as a new patchset (gerrit will track all versions so nothing will be lost).

TL;DR  a change is always 1 git commit, so to make changes use --amend to amend the same change which needing to address review comments.'}, {'account_id': 29823, 'date': '2019-02-11 02:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Could you please add tests for this fix to confirm no further problem.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2019-01-31 11:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/json.html :
"Deserialize fp (a .read()-supporting text file or binary file containing a JSON document) to a Python object using this conversion table."

According to the docs it should work with text and the binary support just added in py 3.6 .

I wonder if you explicitly specify the utf-8 at the open does it solves your issue ?
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36303919/python-3-0-open-default-encoding'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2019-01-31 15:10:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/json.html :
 > "Deserialize fp (a .read()-supporting text file or binary file
 > containing a JSON document) to a Python object using this
 > conversion table."
 > 
 > According to the docs it should work with text and the binary
 > support just added in py 3.6 .
 > 
 > I wonder if you explicitly specify the utf-8 at the open does it
 > solves your issue ?
 > https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36303919/python-3-0-open-default-encoding

I tried to add there the encoding argument as follows:
with open(SAVED_STATE_JSON, encoding='utf-8') as json_file:
...

But that didn't solve the issue, I hit the same traceback again.
This issue is really weird, check my latest comment in the linked launchpad bug.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2019-02-01 07:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Do you run the script with same locale/user (wrapper) ?'}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2019-02-01 10:29:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Do you run the script with same locale/user (wrapper) ?

The user should be the same, however, the issue is reproducible only when running tempest ('tempest cleanup'), so it could meant that there is something with Tempest, with the way how it runs the code, how it wraps it. But no, taking the following output in the account:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1806089/comments/4

it's getting weirder and weirder."}, {'account_id': 22873, 'date': '2019-02-07 14:51:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2019-02-07 15:23:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Fix tempest cleanup for python3

When using python3 the file which is read and
loaded by jsonutils needs to be opened in binary
mode, otherwise, it's causing problems.
It is a known bug [1] in jsonutils from
oslo.serialization module.
The patch also adds a unit test which tests
the loading of a json file.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/oslo.serialization/+bug/1515231

Closes-Bug: #1806089
Change-Id: I3db71c6662d9137a4b75381de7d6dbddd3de4e09
